column4: This place was interesting and had knowledgable people. Great to see that we are saving history, get in free with parks pass.
The Klondike is parked at the shore and is visible but you are not able to board. The history is worth a look see.
this is a nice spot to get good information on the Yukon river, the work done by these boats and the work done by the local nations.

Gold brought people to Whitehorse and the Yukon but without boats like this, sustaining the community in those early days would have been impossible. Built with a shallow draft that permitted running the river even when the water levels were low made it possible to keep the town supplied and to haul gold and other products to market.The original...
It was closed today but I poked around with my camera and got some amazing shots. Very well kept and interesting.

Like many of the things in Whitehorse the S.S Klondike tells a story. The S.S. Klondike is very historical, where you can learn about the past of Whitehorse and how it came to be named the S.S. Klondike. This spot is a great opportunity that i belive you should not miss. So if your stoping in Whitehorse go have a...
The S.S. Klondike has been beautifully restored and is a very interesting look into river travel of the early 1900's.

This is everyones favourite attraction in Whitehorse. Learn all about the history of Gold and see how people got to the Klondike. Lovely boat, lovely setting, Parks Canada. And yes people get married in front of the boat. I know because I'm a marriage Commissioner and I marry lots of lovely people there every year. Winter and summer.
This historic landmark has been well preserved and is iconic of days gone by. There are tours you can join for a more informative walk or just guide yourself.
A National Park attraction. Great visitor experience staff and we'll worth the visit with an overview of the importance of the riverboat during that period.
It is walking distance from the city center, and I would highly recommend visiting this all steam ship. It is a very important part of the Yukon's history that you don't want to miss.
This is a really interesting National Historic Site that tells one of the many fascinating stories of the Yukon. The interior is great & well worth a visit.
The wife and I visited in November. Did not get to see the inside, but was a cool spot for a picture!

This exhibit is free and available to all. It is located in a city park right along the bike/walking path that runs along the Yukon River. We parked the car here and did the exhibit then proceeded down bike/walking path to downtown. Chatted with a few locals on our way to explore some shops and go to dinner. Perfect. Easy...
The tour of this ship grants us a peek into the life of those living during the Gold Rush and how they experienced life and travel on the Yukon River. Clean, well-developed tour.
was a great piece if Yukons history,especially with all the cargo on board to show us what it all carryed,. and all the firewood it needed to run the bolier

The SS Klondike is open 09:30 to 17:00 during the season and admission is free. This was the largest of the British Yukon Navigation Company's fleet and plied the Yukon river between Whitehorse and Dawson City. The stern wheeler has been restored and gives you a glimpse into what life was like before roads when only trains and riverboats linked...
A super well conserved Boat, a must-see when you are in Whitehorse, history, tales, and a journey to the past of the beautiful Yukon River and Northen Territories

We walked through the park and crossed the road to the SS Klondike. Unfortunately it had closed for the season but we were still able to walk around and read the informative plaques that they had on the history of the ship.

a look into a bygone era of river boats, not in the best of repair but certainly worth a visit. Interesting to see how important this form of transport was not too long ago and make one appreciate their importance in trade in early days.

Very interesting old boat, neat to see the real thing, not just a picture. It must have been a tough life with the river, the rapids, the canyon and some big trees floating down. Never mind being the first few boats after the break up of the ice.Spent a comfortable hour here and could have spent another just looking...

Back when I lived in Whitehorse you couldn't board the Klondike. Despite having an arsonist attempt to burn it down some years back this tourist site is a must-see to get a feel for what riverboat traffic was like back during the gold rush.

it is better to visit when it is not rainy, because on rainy days they close the upper deck where you can see the old kitchen, the cabins and the dining room.the visit is very interesting, and you get a good impression of life on board of the Klondike as it was those days.

No trip to Whitehorse, Yukon is complete without a visit to the S.S. Klondike. This ship is situated alongside the Yukon River where it flows through town. You can walk around on the deck and around the grounds where there are placards telling about history of this shipment and the Klondike gold rush.
We visited the S S Klondike as part of our tour of Whitehorse. It is an iconic part of the Yukon's history and has been restored and kept for all to enjoy.
It was cooler when parks Canada did guided tours, but even without its a neat place to visit.There's a lot more to learn in there than you would think!
Great place to visit and learn more about the Yukon history. This is a must if you happen to be in Whitehorse.
Free to get on board that was very nice .....Close your eyes and you are on your way to the Dawson city to strike it rich.
Visited on a rainy day so could not go up on the deck but the parts we did see were well preserved and looked authentic.

This display is very good. The downside is that due to govt cutbacks the upper level has not been maintained and is now closed to visitors. To bad because it looks very good from what we could see. The price is right.... free! A brochures costs you 2.00 and is necessary if you want to do a self tour. The...
We learned a great deal about the Yukon by visiting. The view from the deck of the Yukon River is fabulous.
Well-preserved and historic boat. I learned new information to me about the Yukon River and how it served as a transportation hub.

We got to see the old paddlewheeler for free, because most of it was closed for renovations. Very interesting but I would have loved to get into see all parts of the old boat and not just the cargo deck.

We came for a visit on a rainy day but because of the rain, they did not allow people to visit the upper decks--deemed too slippery. We went back another day to visit the rest of the ship and still we were limited on the upper deck because some structural issues. Use of the walking tour guide is a must...

I was lucky to see the boat on a beautiful day - makes for great photos. It's free and well worth walking around the quick tour (self guided) to see some history. Parks Canada has done a great job with the whole site and upkeep - really cool! It's right on the Yukon river with the Millennium Trail right beside...

This historic stern wheeler and the pleasant park around it is run by the parks service. It is clean and well maintained. The ship is a wonderful lesson in history for children and adults. A visit can last 10 minutes or an hour. It is a good place to stop for a rest on a river hike. The best part...

This is a free attraction but you can pay $2 for the program if you'd like. It's a self-guided tour. You just walk about on the main floor, engine room, crew cabins, etc. You can also check out the main deck but you'll need to walk up using a very narrow staircase with no ramps. The passenger area was closed...
Much of the boat was off limits due to structural problems. Only one staff onboard, and was more concerned about playing ring toss than anything else.
Came to Whitehorse to go mountain bike riding, and knew of the gold rush history. Didn't expect to find a wonderfully preserved steam ship with period cargo. Amazing!

Free to visit, 2.00$ for a brochure, or you can pay for a guided tour. The ship is well set up with recreations of the kitchen, cabins, and storerooms. Interesting to learn about the importance of these vessels to the history of the Yukon.
National Parks is renovating so it was free while I was there. NFB has an 18 minute video they showed explaining navigating the Yukon River with the SS Klondike and sharing its specific history

The Klondike is the largest of the Yukon River paddle wheelers. It's been pulled on shore and supported above the ground to protect it from ice and water damage. It's in very good condition for its age. What makes it particularly interesting is that it's filled with artifacts and cargo, so it's very easy to imagine it's ready to go...
Beautiful ship. I was disappointed that we could not visit the two top decks due to construction but what I saw was great.

It was nice to read all about, but a bit disappointed that a lot of the shipped was roped off so we could only visit a very small section. It is still very educational and a great out of school history lesson for kids.

Loved going through this ship! It was so interesting walking around, and seeing how and with what they loaded on board. Then going upstairs, you can see into the galley and dining room, and it was like you stepped back in time. Thumbs up!

The explanatory video (on continuous loop) gave a good overview of the history of the sternwheeler, which made the tour of the ship itself all the more interesting. The sheer amount of cargo space was staggering, and it was fascinating to see all the different types of goods carried--large quantities of evaporated and powdered milk. Clearly there were not many...

No need to spend a lot of time here but if you have a chance it's worth a visit even if you just want to check it out from the outside. You can do a tour of the boat which I found interesting and helped put the region in perspective.

I have never been on a steamer, and this one has so much history. So interesting to see the different areas. The amount of weight these steamers held is unbelievable. I did not know until boarding it that passengers rode it. The two classes were not real luxury by todays standards. The history of the men that had to load...

Loved going back in time and venturing onto the SS Klondike! Its definitely a must-do upon your travels in Whitehorse. Stop in the tourist info shack before going aboard, you'll find a lot more information about the ship

I wish I could ride a real sternwheeler up to Dawson City! Would beat the 7 hour bus ride I endured just two days ago. Well, if you cant travel the way they did 100 years ago, visiting this exhibit is the best you can do. Beautifully done by Parks Canada and featuring fine young and interesting guides, the boat...

Great to see this piece of history being well preserved - this did mean some areas were roped off because of ongoing work. The guide was excellent and provided a tremendous amount of information about both the ship and the Gold Rush.

Went to SS Klondike – stern wheeler. It is easy to find, as it is right in the downtown Whitehorse area. There was a large parking lot. We watched an 18 minute video in a tent in the parking lot. We toured the stern wheeler on our own after the video. Because we watched the video first, we could make...
This is a great trip with an excellent commentary by a very enthusiastic local. It takes you to where the two mighty rivers meet, and past some historic sites.
I thought it was very interesting to see, but I was quite disappointed because of the fact that some areas were roped off. I did enjoy it though! Worth the visit!
Fantastic historic site. The movie was excellent and very informative. Greg was the host when we were there and he was incredibly knowledgable and friendly!!!

After the trolley ride, we walked to the SS Klondike for a tour thru this very old steamship. We had a guide take us thru telling us of the various areas of the ship and what the ship was used for etc. It was really interesting, worth the walk.

This is located along Waterfront Walkway by Yukon River where we walked from the Informative Centre, close to Main Street and trolley. It is vessel used for transportation in the past, and it provides historical information on the city. The exhibits are well organized and interesting. It is also free admission.
Fascinating riverboat with great historical significance. Very well preserved. Very informative video and signs.
Some sections are roped off although you can look in through windows and doors. There is a printed map for a self guided tour but it lacks details and left me a little unsatisfied,
Very interesting walk through of the SS Klondike paddle boat. We thought the exhibit was well done and worth a stop. Very scenic location and an enjoyable way to spend some time sightseeing.
This is a must see especially if you have never been on a river boat before. It's a tour of with questions and answers by the guides on board. Very nice to learn how and what they were used for.

The SS Klondike is a beautifully-restored sternwheeler, but what's the point if most of it is closed? Our tour group was banned from most of the ship because of structural safety concerns; these should have been proactively dealt with during the off-season, since the Klondike is only open a few months of the year. If the ship was a private...

I found the video very interesting before we visited the actual ship that has been restored. Inside the vessel one sees the wood needed to keep the fires burning and cases of supplies that were hauled along the river.

The visit to the SS is ok, it's too bad that you can only visit one floor of the old boat. However, the video is well worth it and makes the history of the paddle boats on the Yukon River come to life.
We just left this place. Got a lot of nice pictures. Could not view the inside. Ample parking. Near the Yukon river.
A free walkthrough of an old cargo boat with a 20 min video preview of how the river and boats were used and operated back in the early 1900's. Very interesting and authentic.
Very well maintained and quite interesting. There were a lot of areas roped which we would love to have seen the insides of the cabins.

The day we went it was raining heavily so we were unable to go onto the second floor of the boat. You tour the boat on your own although there was a parks Canada staff available to answer questions on the boat and one in the building beside it. After seeing the S.S Keno in Dawson City in which there...
It was January 2010,but very beautiful sunny day and blue sky,really i enjoyed my time with the SS Klondike,i really love it ! :-DGo for it :-)

We travel thousands of miles to see these sights and then Parks Canada does not have enough staff to allow us to tour the entire vessel. Most areas were roped off and had to be viewed from across most of the ship. A heritage sight is for the people not a select few.

This is one of the best if not the best self guided tour of a vessel I've been on. The boat is on dry land and the displays on the boat are just like when it was being used up and down the Yukon River. Get the booklet, just $2.00 Can. This is definitely a must see when in Whitehorse.

This was a very interesting tour tour of a large paddle wheel steamboat. During the tour you get to visit most of the interior and exterior of the boat so you get a real,feel for the size and working of one of these vessels.

Located on the beautiful (and extremely powerful and rapid) Yukon River the SS Klondike is beautifully maintained and restored piece of Yukon history. Great helpful Parks Canada staff gave safety briefings and answered any questions. Glad we did it.

We stopped in to see the S.S. Klondike when we arrived in Whitehorse. They have done a great job setting it up as it was in its hey day. I recommend paying for the self-guided pamphlet as it points out several of the interesting things on the boat.

Visiting the S.S. Klondike takes you back to when this ship was the rapid transit option between Whitehorse and Dawson City. Great to walk through the boat to get a sampling of the way life used to be on the river.

Well done to Parks Canada for maintaining a very important part of the Klondike Gold Rush history,I could almost feel the gold fever as I walked through the S.S. Klondike.The staff were very friendly and knowledgeable.
Some of the SS Klondike was closed when we were there but we still enjoyed the walk through. Due to the renovations, access was free. The Yukon River is beautiful with a fascinating history.

This river steamer has been carefully and lovingly restored, with lots of good interpretive material. What surprised us was the level of detail, including period goods in the "cargo" stacked up on the cargo deck. Unfortunately, we remembered too many of them from our own childhood! (Does that put us in danger of joining the exhibits?)But to assemble all...

Amazing to see the restoration of the S.S. Klondike and learn how this ship and others travelled the Yukon River many years ago. It will be great once further work is carried out and more of the ship is open to the public. A must see if visiting Whitehorse!

The Klondike was centrally located in a very nice park area along the Klondike river. There was a movie about the Klondike that you watch first that was very good. Because it's actual restored that you couldn't go on the uppermost deck which was disappointing. It was free even though it's a national historic site. You had to pay two...

A historical river stern wheel paddle boat. Well presented. Canada parks official exhibit. Free admission but self-guided tour brochure available at a cost. Well worth a look. Good for kids [educational].

The S. S. Klondike is something you have to see to believe. Visitors are required to check in at the city kiosk before going aboard and I suggest you pick up an information flyer. There is a film presentation on the lot that I would recommend viewing before you go onboard. Once onboard you can follow the info pamphlet and...
Enjoyed walking around the ship and learning a bit more of the history. We were able to go up on top which gave us a good perspective of what a person dealt with when traveling this way.
Picked up a brochure from the office near the SSKlondike II. Small charge and then self toured the boat. Boat clean and no tripping hazards.

This is free-to-enter and the lower deck is well laid out. There is limited access to the sun-deck with viewing into one of the cabins, kitch area and dining room but no access at all beyond that. It would be improved if there was access to the upper decks (even outside only), to get a view out from the front...

The SS Klondike is an easy walk from Downtown Whitehorse. Admission is free although you must report to the Parks Office before entering. It is best to watch the video outlining the history of the paddle wheelers before going "on board" in order to gain a better understanding of what you will see. Worth a visit.

A good way to find more out about the Yukon and it's history, with lots of informing and interesting information. About an hour in duration. I would say alone not enough to plan a day around, but if your looking for fun stuff to do with the family to fill up your day, it's always a good way to find...
This was very educational. However it is difficult to go up the narrow stairway if you are not trim. The dinning room was beautiful and the guides were very informative.

This restored paddle wheeler is a focal point in Whitehorse. The video presentation of working days is excellent. The galley replication and menu from the day with a peak of the dining area is very well presented.
You can walk on it! It's not in the water! It looks good with northern lights behind it! In the summer some people dress funny and play croquet in front of it.... I don't like that.

Start by watching the movie of the history of the Yukon river boats this will give you a better idea of what the lifestyle was when these boats were the only way to reach the upper Yukon river area.The boat itself has not aged well as some of it is no longer open to public but still plenty to...

Everyone should take the free tour of the S. S Klondike. It allows one to gain a good understanding of the ship and its role in the history of the Yukon. This is an impressive ship that has been well maintained. It's easy to see why the town had it positioned so that it is the first thing one sees...

Make this part of your "history" tour of Whitehorse! The Beringia Centre, Transportation museum, McBride museum, Trolly Ride, Miles Canyon hike, and Downtown History Walk are all amazing to do and include in your trip, but this was by far our favorite! Friendly, knowledgable staff, and wonderful preservation of this great boat and artifacts!

A had a few hours to kill in Whitehorse, so I went to see the SS Klondike, which is an old paddlesteamer, which has been restored and is part of Parks Canada's exhibits.It's a self guided tour, so you can take as long as you like.Quite neat to see how they used to move supplies back in the...

The SS Klondike is a neat ship to see. There is a lot of history to this vessel and it is one of last remaining. The tour is fun and it is fun to see how people travelled down the Yukon river long ago!

This old, restored paddlewheel steamer is said to be the last to venture up the Yukon River from its many trips to bring Klondike workers and supply up to Dawson City. Now docked on the shores of the Yukon River just east of downtown Whitehorse. Nice walk from downtown hotel to its surround park/grounds.
Local history boards explaining the history of the ship we well kept and very informative. Glad we stopped here, very scenic view.

I had seen a photo of the SS Klondike but only when I stood beside her did the shear size of this magnificent vessel become apparent. This is one big vessel and the hull is in pristine condition,regrettably I was not able to go onboard as the tourist season had not started and she was closed up.There are a...

Looking at the outside of the ship, you might think you have seen what you need to and that there is no reason to stop in. I encourage you to go anyway. It is, for sure, a minor attraction, but stepping aboard and inside the cargo hold, transports you back in time.Parks Canada runs this site and they always...

Our tour guided informed us that the S.S. Klondike was the last of its kind of its era. It is a beautiful structure, clean and well-kept. The paddle wheel is splendid, painted a beautiful bright gold. Though there is not much to do here except walk around and admire the boat, the river and the scenery, it was nice to...

I love this kind of stuff - old boats, old equipment, vintage stuff. The history of travel and commerce on the Yukon River is very interesting. There's a fee to visit but I was happy to contribute towards the curation and renovation of this important piece of local history. Really well set up. Plenty of room around the boat for...

I would suggest visiting this place is worth but on the other hand, the gov't should fund the transformation of this old boat like a mini bar or something outside....Still Pretty outside...we visited under Northern lights tour group...You cannot enter this boat I guess they're preserving this...
It's better in the summer but still great to see in the winter. It's worth a quick stop to see one of our National Historic sites. Take only minutes

We visited in the winter and it was closed at the time. But, I've been in the past during warmer months; I'd suggest a visit for all, certainly those interested in seeing and learning about some Yukon history first hand

We were at SSK at the peak of winter in February and therefore the ship / museum was closed. We could only make a brief photostop. It is a beautiful location on the Yukon river and in the heart of the Whitehorse city; however felt sad since we could not go in or even very close to ship due to...
have to see and i'm not sure if you can even avoid it it is the center of the city and the most prominent site in therelovely to visit
The entire walk along the Yukon river is fantastic. The boat is just a part of the experience. Amazing place.
Spend time for the self guided tour and see what its like 100 years ago travelling to Whitehorse on the river on a paddle wheel ship. Well worth it and beautiful photos.
great place for all,learn about history in the Yukon,great tours and information provided ,right by the Yukon river
It was very cool to see this old boat but there was not a lot of info about the boat. Pictures are cool, right on the banks of the yukon river.
Walked around the Klondike in the snow. Impressive old ship and unfortunately not open. Loved seeing it though. Paddle wheel was huge.

Explore a true piece of Yukon history but stepping on the SS Klondike. Ask the Parcs Canada employees (French services available) about the Gold Rush's era and the preservation of the ship. Don't miss the upper deck and the view of the magnificent dinning area, sooooo glamourous! Amazing to think it was not so long ago that people came to...

We visited the Yukon in the middle of winter, so the klondike was not open for visitors. It is available for private functions and tours by the public over the summer months. It has a great story, and the amount of energy and the stories associated with this unique character ship are well worth the trip out to see it...
Beautiful and very interesting! It was really cool to learn about how it worked and the importance of these boats before there were roads in the Yukon wilderness.

A must see while you are in Whitehorse. There is a movie and Parks Canada staff on the boat to explain and answer questions. There is no charge but you do pay $2.50 or so for the guild book. Well worth it. There is a small Gift Shop there as well.

Strolling about the SS Klondike, with museum exhibits all over the floating ship, makes you feel like you are really there. Also there was a media presentation in an adjacent tent. Don't miss this icon of Yukon history.

Two options, you can walk around it and take pictures in a lovely park, or you can pay to see a video about the history and wander around on board (dry-docked). Very informative, interesting to see how folks lived and traveled when it was active.
This was a free tour of the SS Klondike. It was very interesting and the vessel has been very well cared for. This a must stop in Whitehorse.
It's a boat, on the side of a lake, that doesn't go anywhere. It's well maintained and worth a look if you're heading down to the mighty Yukon River in Whitehorse.
The last and the largest back peddler to travel to and from Dawson City, carrying the ore and equipment.
Super disappointed this attraction from Parks Canada was closed by September 1. They couldn't have made it to Labour Day?

It is great fun to visit the S. S. Klondike. You get a walking tour with great information about the boat, her travels and how she was operated. Children have a great time and all seem to say that they loved their visit. I did my tour with other adults and all of us have a fun visit.

Popped in here on my way around the Millennium Trail. Unfortunately, the upper levels were mostly closed off and inaccessible due to structural issue when I was there. The areas that I was able to access were interesting.....kinda cool to see how old some well-known companies are!! (Alymer, Rexall Drugs, Nabisco Shredded Wheat etc). The boat makes for some nice...
Very nice ride on an old fashioned paddle boat. Historically there were hundreds used on the Yukon river. We say a quaint First Nation village and some beautiful scenery.
beautiful site right on the river. the boat is in various states of repair. the guides on the boat brought the history to life. Well worth a visit
This was the largest of all Sternwheelers to travel the upper Yukon. I You can get a guided tour....whih is great if you like history. You can also do self guided.

Can you imagine 250 paddlewheelers plying the waters of the Yukon River at the turn of the century? A tour of this steam ship brings back the days when boats had to stop every 20 miles along the river to load up with wood. The hard life everyone endured is hard to imagine. Visit Whitehorse and take the tour. You...

Take in the film in the tent first to give you the background. We did the self guided tour with the (purchased) brochure and found it interesting as my audience was a couple of seniors and I read it out to them. The areas are marked well and correspond to the brochure write up. The dining room was not accessible...

This is a historic site preserved to educate tourist on the Klondike Gold Rush days. A great way to appreciate the hard work of the pioneers who made it happen. The 20 min movie at the visitor centre will be great for you to understand why this claims to be historic site.

Interesting self-tour of a steamer that was once used to transport goods for trade and mining. There are displays of the products that were shipped. You can look into the dining room to see how passengers and crew lived while on the vessel. You can also see the engine. When the sun is going down, the light for photography is...
Located on the Yukon River, this is a real gem which closed a week ago which was too bad. There is lots of parking.
this 100 year old ship has been restored to the time of the gold rush and once on it you have a sense of what it was like to travel up the yukon. Staff are friendly and helpful.

Two of us toured the vessel for a $2 fee to pay for the brochure. It is a piece of living history, a key to the development of the Yukon. There are few such ships remaining. An interesting tour. Too bad the upper decks were not open for the tour. Walk around back to take in the size of the...

Lovely boat to look at. Video int he adjacent tent is really interesting. The boat is being lovingly restored and stocked as in the previous years. I found it very interesting. I am in awe of the fortitude of the people that came live and worked here 150 years ago, and for thousands of years before that! Grit and determination...

My kids really enjoyed visiting this cite. The S.S. Klondike is in great shape. Be sure to stop by the visitors center for an orientation from the park staff, and be sure to view the film in the white tent next to the ship. Also, be sure to peek into the galley on the second floor...
Right along the riverfront walkway and Robert Service Way, walking distance from downtown. Worth visiting if you have some free time in town.
not much to see as you cannot get to much of the ship. Would have liked to see the dining room and other closed areas.
We always enjoy stopping and seeing this part of history. There's a park with bathrooms & picnic tables where we always have lunch
This isn't a drive by. I felt like I went back in time. It is being restored to be used for celebration purposes and parties. I think it will be even more amazing when it is finished.

Very informative film, then a self-guided walking tour ($2) of the ship. A Park's employee was on board the S.S. Klondike to answer any questions. Very well-preserved ship. Unfortunately some areas are not off limits to tourists for safety reasons. We spent about an hour here.
For a good overview of the steamboat experience for earlier age travelers to the Yukon, consider a tour of the SS Klondike.

Did a self guided tour which was very brief as the 2 upper decks were closed for refurbishment. It is worth the money if you have the time. Guided tours are also available but at a substantially higher price.

I love historic sites. I visited while it was raining so we couldn't go to the upper deck, but it was a great piece of history and Whitehorse has taken great pride in this boat. Parks Canada employees were very informative also
Quite remarkable what went on on the Yukon in the riverboat days of the gold rush and beyond.Most of the boat's deck and interior is exposed for a good view of how it worked
If walls could talk, would it have a story to tell. History is so thick inside these walls you could cut it with a knife!

We visited this place two years ago while on our way to Skagway, Alaska. We always stop by the Tourist Information Center wherever we go. It's a must for any traveler. You can get all the information or most of it by merely stopping and asking the information staff members. The S.S. Klondike can be boarded free of charge ,so...

Spent an hour touring the boat and short film offered by parks Canada.Our information officer was a local and he shared lots of facts of SS Klondikes adventures and the atlin barge also onsite. Nice river pathway to sit enjoy river views.
It was only about 100 years ago that this was the route to the Yukon once the ice had broken on the rivers to allow passage. Certainly wasn't a luxurious way to travel.
self guided tour through a paddle-wheeler that worked the Whitehorse, Dawson route during the gold rush.
Excellent self-guided tour... we learned a lot! The person working at the site was very helpful and informative. A great time!

First of all, it's free to go on-board, so no reason not to visit. Stop at the visitors center first and they'll explain it all. It's great that this ship was saved for posterity and it was interesting to visit the various parts of the ship. For example, they have the hold decked out as if the ship was loaded...
interesting history, just a short visit ,not reallyy a major interest but they have done a nice job making the waterfront area attractive

We could only go on the main deck where the engines and supplies were stored. One deck was closed because it was raining and the others were not available anytime. The artifacts were awesome. We thoroughly enjoyed the visit.
We enjoyed walking through the old sternwheeler. Wish we could have seen the old dining area but it was closed.

We did the self guided tour for $2. It was very neat to see. You could easily understand what you were looking at. The only downside is that parks Canada is doing maintenance on the second and upper most decks of the ship. You could catch a glimpse of the first class dining rooms through the galley (ships kitchen) The...

Interesting to look at but not a place to spend a lot of time unless you really enjoy reading.It is cool to walk thru though and have a look at everything, and it is restored really well. Attraction is free, but they want you to spend $2 on a brochure for a self guided walk. Worth the price for...

The SS Klondike is a steam-powered sternwheeler that carried passengers, cargo, and ore up and down the Yukon River. Now restored and safely located on dry land, this vessel is available for your examination. There is also a video that provides additional information.

This preserved piece of Yukon history by Parks Canada shows in part what it must have been like living in the area in days gone by. Well presented with knowledgeable staff who show great enthusiasm for their work.

This ship is very well preserved and provides a fascinating insight into the gold rush past. A definite recommendation, though sadly some areas of the boat are inaccessible at the moment due to structural problems.

There was no charge to go onto the boat, but the brochure for the self-guided tour cost $2 CAD. But only a few of the items in the brochure were available and the rest were blocked off from the public.
Too bad the federal government stopped the complete tours, a very interesting piece of Canadian history.
WhenIi lived here in the 60's there were 3 boats unfortunately a fire destroyed 2 of them. Very well restored and worth the visit.
Lets you see what is was like back then. I loved the music playing up top and the chance to see the dining room.

We were slightly stunned to learn that this great National Historic Site is still free (although you can pay $2.00 for an informative brochure at the check in kiosk) There is a must see video in the tent just beyond the entrance to the steam wheeler that really gives you a feeling of what it must have been like to...

The Klondike has been expertly preserved with each area supplied items to give it life. In the Storage area there are boxes of dry goods and barrels of liquid products. The Staterooms have the doors open so visitors may see the insides. The dining room and lounge are laid out as if waiting for new passengers. The Galley is fully...

We stopped at the SS Klondike which is a historic site with Parks Canada. There was no charge to visit the paddlewheeler so off we went. They have a great display of life on the boat during the Klondike gold rush. The Parks Canada Interpretive guide was so informative and gave alot of history and stories about the era and...
What awesome piece of history,very good restoration,beautiful location on the edge of the Yukon river.

Beautifully restored. Good visual info and personal informed on stern wheeler .. Good film on area. We felt the displays informative and illustrated events. Ship on water walkway picnic tables available.
We visited the SS Klondike on June 1 - the first day it was open. Very informative of how a steam ship operated. Staff were busy getting the ship open.

Some of the displays on the S.S. Klondike were closed for refurbishment so the price to see it was free. At that price, it was definitely a bargain. The ship is nicely restored and one gets a real sense of what it was like when the ship was operating on the Yukon River.The grounds where the S.S. Klondike are...
This site is worth visiting. We were there in December at sunrise (10.30 am) and it was so pretty. We couldn't go on board as it was out of season but I sure it would be worth doing in summer.
The boat ride was interesting but because of the sound system it was very hard to hear the information. A better sound system would make it more worthwhile.
It felt historically to go aboard this beautiful ship. Time felt like it hadde stopped. Well-preserved and beautiful.

The paddle wheelers were the main method of transportation during the gold rush of 1898 and continued until well into the 20th century. The exhibit helped to explain how vital these boats were to bring in food and supplies (lots of liquor!) and carry out the gold.
We enjoyed this riverboat cruise. There was lots of nice scenery. There are snacks and drinks available onboard and a good narrator.

This is a great site to visit. The ship is beautifully restored, the info in the pamphlet ($2) and small visitor centre is interesting and well done, and best of all, it's free! There aren't any signs in the ship, so be sure to pick-up a pamphlet to better understand what you're looking at. Try and go on a non-rainy...

I finally went into the exhibit, watched the movie of what it was like to pilot the paddle wheeler through often treacherous waters on the way to and from Dawson City's gold fields.This historic Gov't of Canada site is well worth the wait to climb aboard and see how travellers experienced the journey along the Yukon river.
Beautifully restored paddlewheeler worth touring. Used to be a guided tour full of information but our government made some cuts. Takes a good hour to really experience the tour properly.
an old freight steamer that you can tour. a little disappointed that only a small portion of the boat was open. THE Film was the best part. free for both. A self guiding map $2.
And this attraction helps one get more deeply acquainted with the recent history of the area. Even in winter the structure is imposing & interesting

What I saw of the ship was great, I liked the supplies they had piled up and the quarters for the workers. I was very disappointed that we couldn't go into the dining room area or a room where the passengers stayed. You could peek through to see in but that was all. The railings while authentic weren't very safe....

When in Whitehorse, take a walk down to this lovely historical site, or take the Whitehorse Waterfront Trolley and take a very short walk to the site right on the river. It's an original 1937 sternwheeler saved from dereliction. The Parks Canada tour starts off in a wall tent giving the background info on this vital River transport link, from...
Very interesting for my husband who into history much more than I.But I did enjoy seeing the dinning room.
A very welcome stop for us at the Klondike. A look at the ship and understanding its place makes for a better understanding of yukon trade and history.
Wasn't open for viewing - but still interesting to look at this attraction. Historical. Within walking distance of downtown Whitehorse.
If you are driving to Alaska and stop here, see the Klondike. If you are driving the highway, this is the reason you drove, to see the history and sights along the way. Vewry interesting.
only open for tours in the summer, but was still neat to see in the winter. can't wait to check it out in the summer months.
Great bit of history, but could only walk around the outside as it is closed during winter!Come on Whitehorse! Loads of visitors in winter.....open a few historical sites!
This place not far from city center. It's the ship from Gold rush era basically but I was more attracted to the river just beside this ship. It was beautiful with all the colorfull trees.
There are only tours during the summer. This boat is still worth a look in the winter but you can only look at the outside. It is lit up at night too. No fee to see the outside.

recent restoration with incredible attention to detail make this better than ever.every tarp, towel, napkin, etc. redone/refurbished. fascinating even for those landlubbers like myself. no cost spared in restoration, needs to be seen by all to be adequately appreciated.
Very interesting History and Tour. Highly Recommended - BUT call in advance to verify access because recent budget cuts have restricted tours and hours substantially.
Usually I only walk by. haven't been on a tour in years. Not sure what they're like thanks to Stephen Harpers cuts to our National Parks

We visited this lake ship on winter and it was very, very cold. But this is a wonderful piece of history from the gold rush at the Yukon. The river, the close mountains are the perfect frame for this attraction. You got to visit!

Really worth while spending some time on the boat. Gives you an authentic experience of post gold rush era. Too bad Harper thinks history should be changed to suit his whims, not preserved for all to admire. PC government cut so much money to parks and historic sites in the Yukon the SS Klondike can not have guided tours any...

Didn't enter the boat/museum since it is in the month of December, it's closed. But you will see this as you walk along the trails along the Yukon river. There is a small shelter near this boat that we almost missed, and it has stories/history of this boat and Whitehorse.
Would have loved to be able to go inside the boat more, but peeking through the windows was enough to see some of the cool artifacts they have!
It was closed because it was winter but you must go anyway because it's such an amazing photo spot.....The Klondike history I found interesting, especially how she got to that spot.
nice restored ship, but could not board it was locked down?located in a nice park on the yukon river.
Very interesting and full of history of the Yukon. I enjoyed it Immensely! The tour guides were very knowledgable of the ship, and could answer questions about the ship that weren't part of the tour.

I love the way this stern wheeler has been preserved in history. It tells us the story of the Klondike gold rush. So many features to see & admire. Lovely place for wedding photos as well as school trips.

Largest river boat that ran on the Yukon River between Whitehorse and Dawson City. It has been preserved by Canada Parks in a great setting along the Yukon River. Every Christmas the City of Whitehorse lights up the boat.
This was well worth the admission price and great photo opportunities were presented. The guide was friendly and knowledgable.

We were fascinated by the pictures and stories of the riverboats that we saw at the Transportation Museum and the MacBride Museum. Having a real riverboat to check out was something we really looked forward to. Unfortunately, it is a Parks Canada operation and had already closed for the season. We could only admire it from a distance. We visited...

From the outside, SS Klondike looks like it would be a very interesting attraction. Unfortunately, it is closed from Labour Day.It is a short walk from the centre of Whitehorse. It is not big so even reading all the historical information and touring the inside probably won't take more than 1/2 hour.

We were the last people admitted on the day we went. Missed the last tour. As I was flying out and couldn't return the gate person took pity on us and let us aboard for free, which was nice. We didn't get a guided tour as a result but the staff were great at explaining things.This is a great...
we were very fortunate to be there the last day they were open for the season , interesting to see how they used to travel !
Take a tour and see what it was like back in the day to travel the might Yukon River! Don't forget the ss Keno in dawson city

We , my father and later my cousin was here several times at the year 1980 with a big truck from south Canada , Oliver B.C. to bringing the fresh farm products , selling to the northern people . For me a hungarian guy who was just escaped out behind The Iron Curtain was a dream come true . I...

We were here too early in the day so we weren't able to tour the interior of the boat. The public is able to walk around the exterior and along the river. There is a plaque explaining the history of the boat.

This was an interesting place to visit. They want you to watch a short video before you go on the boat. That video was quite interesting especially since we stopped at a view point on the way to Dawson City that was featured in the video. The SS Klondike was easy to find and it was easy to imagine what...

The boat was in service until the 1950's which is really astounding. It has been placed on dry land and is well preserved. Most of the areas are accessible or viewable. It is a very interesting look at what travel was like just 60 or so years ago on the Yukon. Tour is self guided and with the aid of...
Wonderful example of what it was like to travell the Yukon Rivers so long ago. Compare then to now and you can get an idea of why we have a much longer lifespan.

This is a self-guided tour with a brochure that is detailed and there are signs through out the boat. If you ever wondered what it was like to travel back at the turn of the last century and even up to the 1950's, this is the place to see what luxury was like back then. We found the boat to...

We took a self guided tour of this boat. It was very interesting to see what the inside looked like and what it transported so many years ago. There was Park personnel available to answer any questions. I would go see this again.

Definitely do the Parks Canada tour on this historic paddle wheeler! It's one of 3 remaining paddle wheelers you can view that are still around from the days of '98 (1898 that is). The 1 hour tour is done extremely well for anyone who likes a bit of history and really wants to understand just why these were the Boeing...

This is a really nice historical site. The boat is restored so that you have a very good idea of what it was like to travel down/up the river on the Klondike. Short intro movie helps a lot by putting it into context. But the star of the show is the restoration. I can just picture myself as a first...
This is a lovely piece of history and well worth the time to walk there and tour the ship. The video in the little theatre is interesting and adds to the local history and knowledge.
we particularly enjoyed the short introductory movie on the history of the SS Klondike. it makes the ship come to life. Everything is well kept and clean.

its was only about 100 years ago, that steam was the only power they had. now look at it. anyways, very nicely re-stored. glad they took the time to save a very important part of history.its a free attraction.

For a free attraction, this is pretty amazing. The short film in the tent is a must see.We learned a great deal about travel on the Yukon river back in the gold rush days. It’s a great location and makes for an enjoyable couple of hours. My tax dollars well spent. Afterwards you can walk the boardwalk along the...

What an amazing stern wheeler! One could almost hear the voices from the past as we toured the decks. If only its walls could speak. The site where this ship is dry docked is really impressive with the beautiful surrounding view and the park alongside it allowed for an enjoyable picnic. You will be very impressed with this tour as...
A a parks Canada site. The paddle wheeler has been beautifully restored to its original state. Excellent movie about the the functions of the riverboats and life on the river. Well with a visit.
This site is absolutely amazing from the staged dining area to the kitchen and sleeping quarters. The size and history of this paddle wheeler is incredible. Definitely a must see!

Full of history and very interesting. I have seen people post that there is a fee, we didn't have to pay one so I'm not sure why, not on a tour or anything. It is worth stopping by, watch the video first, it puts things in perspective.
This just has to be worth a visit. Well preserved and presented, you can just imagine how it was aboard all those years ago. Lots of interesting bits to look at.A must when in Whitehorse.

I'm not one for attractions like the S.S Klondike, but for a staple like this, you must see it. The staff are friendly and helpful, the self guided tour is interesting, and the view from the Klondike is stunning.

I love boats and history so this was a perfect match. This ship is a beautiful example of a restored river boat that used to ply the Yukon River before the roads went in. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed the tour. It was so interesting to see how tiny the spaces were that people used to work...
Very well done and provided very informative information during the time it operated. Enjoyed the ability to explore the whole ship.

The S.S. Klondike is a great Canadian National Historic Site. There is no charge for this site.You can first watch a movie if you want. The ship is dressed both inside and outside to fit the vintage, very well done.You can access all three levels but not the wheelhouse.There was two S.S. Klondike built. This is S.S....
Enjoyed a trip on the river to see the sights as the we had read in the travel brochure. Good weather and relaxing sightseeing. Good inclusion on our visit to Whitehorse.

We loved our time touring this fascinating national site. It is thoughtfully recreated, and really takes the visitor back in time with many details that illustrate the life and times of this sternwheeler. Don't miss the film shown in the tent beside the boat: it has amazing footage of actual sailings, showing the workers and guests, and highlighting the challenges...

We stopped on our way from Skagway, spent the afternoon touring about. The parks canada presentation is very well done. The props and lay out, the self guided tour really allow you to walk back in time, the park is clean and well maintained. It is free, donations are welcome. Everyone should take an hour to visit this part of...

Parks Canada (on site) provides a comprehensive brochure titled "self-guided tour", with thorough explanations of the various parts of the SS Klondike.Restoration has been extremely well done befitting the "National Historic Site" designation. To envision the hardships of moving people, food, supplies and equipment without roads, clarifies why there were over 200 sternwheelers on the Yukon River and adjoining...
This free attraction is well worth a visit. The history of the vessel is clearly explained from its building through to its conversion into a museum piece.
Touring the ship was a great reminder of days gone by. The staff was very helpful and explained everything well. It was also free to tour!

This was my third time checking out the S. S. Klondike. This time I was with my young daughter. It was so meaningful to be able to walk around the ship and look in the rooms that are staged to reflect that time period. I liked that we could go at our own pace. I also liked the setting beside...
Great free attraction at the riverfront. See the video first. Only downside was that the wheelhouse wasn't open!
Loved the self guided tour - very fascinating and historical. It's one of the reasons we stayed an extra day in Whitehorse-we didn't want to miss out on visiting.

I have visited the S.S. Klondike two times now, and have learned new things both times. It is an interesting view into life in the Interior before the Alaska Highway, when travel and the delivery of goods was limited by the seasons.
Lovely to see the boat set up inside as it would have been when it was active. They have done a good job of maintaining the boat.

The short film in the tent near the SS Klondike really set the scene for life and work on the river in the early days. Touring the boat almost made you fell as if it could push off and head to Dawson at any time. I love the history and with a little imagination the SS Klondike and the river...

SS Klondike was closed on our mid-September visit so it was on our agenda this spring. Was very pleasantly surprised when I showed up at the staffed visitors centre. Short chat from the staff, supplied with an informative brochure and sent on my way...free. Yes free. Spent an hour roaming thru the signs, picture, plaques and movie. Not sure when...

If you like history or like myself love photography, then don't miss this place! It's free to tour and a unique look at how transportation was back in the day! It's a nice walk before or after dinner.

We had the opportunity to tour the S.S. Klondike while in Whitehorse. The vessel has been restored by Parks Canada and is a wonderful example of the ships that played the Yukon River. As you view the various areas of the ship, you quickly appreciate the difference between first class accommodations and crew accommodations. The self-tour is free and well...

We got involved in the Yukon's Passport opportunity this year. This is one of the spots on your exploration of Whitehorse. Enjoyed it from the ground floor to the ringing, gently of the bell at the top of the ship.

Very informative and surprising that in that time period this ship was appointed as it was. The sun deck and dining room was very nice. There were 4 or 5 lifeboats that held 20 passengers but we did find the information on how many passengers were on board at a time. Very nice.

We really enjoyed touring the SSKlondike....The video before you go on the Paddlewheel boat..was informative & made the self guided tour even better. Touring the boat helped history come alive for us....This was a free Parks Canada attraction.

This attraction is free! Go to the info booth first to get your brochure for a self-guiding tour. I also recommend you stop in the tented area and watch the 18 minute film of some great old footage showing how these types of boats were so vital to the building of the towns. You can walk all over the boat...
This was free and very worthwhile. We learned a lot about the role these steamships played in the early days.

Mighty barge... 200 tons and only 3-4 ft immersionfeel the smell of old wood and greasefantastic paddlewheeler! Walk around from bottom to upper high class roomsdont forget to see ViC (visitor information center) with maps, old photosaaa and get stamp for Yukon Gold Price :)

Oh how I'd love to have had an opportunity to travel to Dawson City on one of these elegant sternwheelers! This fully restored vessel is an excellent example of the type and is as authentic as they come. Well worth a visit!

We chose to do a self guided tour. The visitors center gave us a well written brochure to help guide us through this very historical steam boat. Prior to boarding the ship we saw an eighteen minute movie on the history of the boat and the rivers it sailed on. We were amazed to see what a beautiful job they...

This is a well preserved Paddle Wheeler and entry fee gets you a good guided tour. You'll get a good background to the gold rush and well as a feel for how these boats operated.When on the tour, I had a real sense of the excitement the arrival of the first boat brought after break up. People must have...
This is history at its best to be able to walk around this great example of the paddle wheeler and hear the stories of the Klondike .

It was freezing when we went to visit. However it gave an impression on just how hard it would be to live in those times. The true spirit and the determination of the people who went before was inspiring. As the travel by river from Whitehorse to Dawson City it must have been hard in those days when you thought...
This is a very nice old paddle wheeler right on the river. Clearly a tourist attraction, but still nice to visit. :-)
The history of the SS Klondike is interesting and the tour is well presented. The artifacts are very well preserved. It is definitely worth doing.

The S.S. Klondike tour gives all visitors a glimpse of life in the Yukon in the 1900s. Great for kids and adults to learn about the history of travel in the Yukon and see and understand the workings and challenges of paddlewheelers.

There isn't really a lot to do here but marvel at the sight of one of the original paddle-wheelers that plied the waters of the Yukon River during the gold rush.The ship (is it called a ship?) is dry-docked and restored to it's former glory, fresh white paint and red trim on display.Nice photo op down by the...

The staff were very friendly and the self guided tour was very informative. The boat is staged with period items many of them from when the Klondike was in use. Excellent spot for photos and to just sit and take in the scenery.

The self-guided tour of the S.S. Klondike provided a hands-on glimpse into the history of the region and a sense of the era. One could spend several hours or, in our case due to schedule, just a brief visit. Either way, one gains a insight into the rich history.
Only saw the outside but it is an example of Yukon history and the means of transportation years ago --quite wonderful

It was very interesting to find out about the history of the Klondike and the ships that carried the people to the gold fields. The officer at the information booth was also very informative and presented the details very professionaly.
Board the SS Klondike to experience history. A full size riverboat that hauled passengers and freight during the goldrush.
We were there too late to climb aboard but made awesome pictures and enjoyed the history behind the SS Klondike.

This historic paddle steamer is a great way to fill in 60 minutes, to see what it is actually like to be on a boat of this size, the critical part it played in local transport & developing the area before cars n planes. Great friendly staff onboard to fill in the gaps that you can't read about.

Was absolutely an amazing tour of the boat. It was interesting to see the movie before the tour and hard to believe how much wood was needed to fire the engines, The tour of the boat was great, the lounge, the galley, the whole boat was amazing,
Very interesting and well-maintained. Welcoming Parks Canada staff friendly and helpful. Well worth a visit.

This Parks Canada attraction has been beautifully restored, and should not be missed when visiting Whitehorse. The short film beforehand really set the stage for the self-guided tour of the boat. The displays show what life was really like during that time frame.
we stopped here to see the s.s. Klondike, too bad we were late to go inside, we though walked around , nice that this is drydocked on the river edge

I give this a 2 simply because the attraction was closed as of Labour Day! I guess the YT Tourist group think no tourists venture to Whitehorse after August! What a disappointment to learn that the major attraction was closed after venturing across Canada to see it!Locals say this is very worthwhile seeing but check for opening and closing...

Unless you are really into these sorts of things, I would recommend a quick picture and walk around as you make your way to the path around the river and local parks. It's a photo op near the beginning of a nice trail system.

In the course of our trip, we'd heard a bit about the steamers that used to serve the Yukon River and associated lakes. This site gave us all the details as well as a chance to climb all over the boat.
We really enjoyed this tour -- one of us for the "people" side of the history, the other for the "machinery" side. What a treat to find an attraction that doesn't charge a fat admission fee!
No charge. Enjoyed self guided tour. Gate attendant was excellent. Very personable and knowledgable,
Excellent example of Yukon steamer, free, very informative personnel. Very well restored, maintained

Must stop and see this. A snap shot of how it would have been to travel or work on a riverboat in a really remote area. The attention to detail was impressive. The amount of time to set up the boat must have taken hours. Way to go Parks Canada and the people that made this possible.
Very well set up. Excellent short movie, as well as information brochure for self-tour. Another plus is that it was free!

Very interesting sternwheeler to explore. Amazing what it was like in the days when passengers were in these tiny rooms for a trip up the Yukon River. The video presentation was so informative and just seeing what the goldminers went through was incredible. A must see.
Be sure to watch the film. Amazing that footage still exists! Very pleasant, interesting nice trip into the past

We visited the SS Klondike just before leaving Whitehorse and getting back to France, I was very surprised as it was for free (you can leave an offering). We were welcomed by a guide at the office very professional, he gave us a plan in French and was very nice. The boat is in a very good shape considering the...
It was fascinating to see how the staff and passengers lived, how the ship moved and the layout of the ship. Well worth the visit.

It is an honour to walk around such piece of goldrush history...artifacts are AMAZING. The dining room tables are all set, and one can just invasion the patrons, dressed in their finest, dining there.One of the sleep quarters has a pair of long johns hanging on a clothesline to dry...So nostalgic...

This was a truly wonderland way to spend an hour. We learnt so much about the bygone days of the stern wheel riverboats and those who travelled in them. There's a film to watch before you 'board' which gives a fascinating history into life on the Yukon, and the whole exhibit is free of charge. The Parcs Canada guide on...

This was a wonderful exhibit. Be sure to go and see the film prior to touring the boat. It is a self-guided tour and it is free. It was one of the most interesting pieces of history in the area. Unbelievable history lesson. We took a lot of pictures and a guide in the wheel house provided exceptional information on...
Interesting to see how learn the history of the river trade and the boats that served the communities. Worth the visit.
It was a great example of the gold rush. Parks Canada was doing some work so a small staircase was only open to get up to the top but that happens
S.S. Klondike is a great visit in all ways for all ages. Be sure to watch the video of steamboats on the Yukon River: it's incredible adventure!

Best ship tour. While we were there it was free and self-guided. That will probably change. The ship is fully restored and you walk through the entire thing and see crew quarters, guest quarters, all provisions they would carry, and of course the engine room. Really a fun, interesting visit.

A very well done restoration of the river stern wheeler from early 1900's. Felt like we were embarking on a river cruise - all the cargo and passenger areas were set-up like the original. Only disappointment was we couldn't get into the wheelhouse due to handrail regulations being debated between local government and the ship restoration society.

.....the riverboat sternwheelers were the way prospectors got to Dawson and the gold.A wonderful heritage museum, amazing in its load-carrying capacity and beautifully preserved in a lovely location.Visit it.
This old sternwheeler has been set up to look just like it did when it was being used everyday. Well worth the time to see how things were.

This ship is a well restored example of the paddlewheelers that plowed the Yukon waters at the turn of the last century. We bought the combined ticket with the McBride museum and walked over with the guide. I was not particularly interested in the ship but it represents an important part of the opening of the north. You can also...

This old ship was amazing. It really tells a story and let's you appreciate the struggles that the people who built this land endured. The video was very informative and to top it all of the exhibit was free.

First, a superb movie by Crawley Films of the ships history. Then on board...wow..cases of everything from reindeer milk to booze.An amazing view of the engineering of this ship, to say nothing re the accommodations and wheelhouse. Oh that more Canadians could visit this incredible ship. And, No Charge!!

Gave a very good insight into riverboat traffic on the Yukon. Watch the continuous video and then visit the riverboat. Also consider the walking/hiking trail that continues after the riverboat. We saw the fish ladder and hydroelectic dam.

Just interesting to go on board and see some historical aspects of travel from this part of Canada. Very interesting to see the different sleeping quarters and how the upper class was treated compared to lower class.

Located on the Yukon river at the edge of town, this steamer ship is well preserved- the cabins and dining room are as they were in the day. A very informative Canadian park service guide was present on the lower deck to answer any and all questions. He was knowledgeable and enthusiastic, which added to the experience. There are photos...
Watch the video; go into the kiosk that explains the history and tour the actual boat - simply amazing!

Coming from a country where our Public Museums are completely free I am constantly shocked by the outrageous prices and poor quality offered my many Museums in many countries. However Whitehorse is an exception. The Museums are very good and the SS Klondike is one of the better ones. It is free and "self guided". You are given a brochure...

A cool little museum that offers some insight into the history of the river and the people who travelled it. A great stop off if you are going to walk the millenium trail along the river. Its nothing fantastic but interesting and free just the same. thanks Parks Canada.
It is an old ship, firmly resting on ground. It is quite large and I found the steam engine interesting.

The SS Klondike was one of the last shallow-draught paddlewheel steamers used to supply the communities along the Yukon river between Whitehorse and Dawson City. It is expertly preserved by Parks Canada and displayed on the riverbank at Whtehorse. You get great views of the Yukon river from the deck of the vessel, and the mountains to the south and...

Probably one of the best kept historic sites I have seen. So well preserved and allowed visitors to get up close, tour the entire ship. Excellent recreation of typical bunks, dining room, observation room etc.

In 2013, the SS Klondike is open to the public at no charge for self-guided tours. A brochure points out the main points on the ship, and a Parks Canada staff member comes on board to answer questions when time allows. Formal tours are available by booking ahead with a private contractor.

My wife and I enjoyed the S.S. Klondike. Due to budget cuts, the Canadian Park Service provided a pamphlet for a self-guided walking tour of the vessel. We really enjoyed taking a step back into history aboard the Klondike. The pamphlet was good, and the vessel is in great shape. The Klondike is a must see stop in Whitehorse; these...

This national historical site is a gem located in downtown Whitehorse. The National Parks employees are extremely knowledgable and provide a great tour and plenty of insight into the Yukon's past.Well worth your time and an excellent value for a piece of history.

Have you ever seen a boat that could change the shape of its hull, walk itself forward off a shoal, and draw only a couple of feet of water while transporting many tons of goods against the river current, all fueled with wood? This is the most amazing feat of engineering and a glimpse into thwe history of settlement of...
They are closing down this park. so hoping it is still around. It is closed inside. used to be open in summer.
The history that is imparted here is amazing. the cords of wood needed to fuel these machines and the conditions one lived in to ride on this boat. You must see this boat, inside and out.

learn a bit about the history of yukon territory and what it was like to travel up the yukon river in search of gold fields in dawson... guided tour excellent, with informative guides happy to dispense their knowledge of environs and beyond!!
Took the self guided tour. The recreations and preservation are delightful, no detail is spared. Definitely worth a few bucks and an hour of your time.
The history they packed in that boat was wonderful! It made it more real putting yourself in the place of the passengers and the crew

Managed a self guided tour on the last day of the season. Unfortunately they were starting to pack up the artifacts as we were touring, would have been nice to have that done after the tours were done for the day. Boat is well looked after and in a very well maintained park. Brochure for the self guided tour was...
Very well put together displays, interesting history. We particularly liked the photographs that were left for us to look at, it gave us a real feel for the life as a traveller on the river.

We love this place. NIcely reconstructed. By the Millennium trail, so perfect to go for a walk after the visit. This year is the last time they have guided visits thanks to federal budget cuts. It is very unfortunate because it was one of the very few places where activities were in French or in English.

Have done a great job on restoring it and presenting it as it would have been when it was running the river. We didn't do the guided tour, just self-guided and the information booklet you get was able to explain the workings and doings of the boat. Was well worth having a look at.

This boat looks very nicely restored...but we didn't get to go inside...apparently it has very restrictive hours of operation...we didn't understand why it wasn't open for people to explore...I mean they don't have to have tours available all the time...but let people go in and see it....How often are people in the Yukon?! It's not exaclty something where you can...
Quaint interesting decor. A tad pricey but the food was delicious and everyone was every happy with their dishes.
The Klondike has been well preserved and provides a great flavour of the times. The tour guide was knowledgeable and friendly. And the film on the barge really helped set the atmosphere.
Lots of authentic items on board give you a great feel for what travel was like in the gold rush era. I esp. enjoyed the dining room, sitting lounge and kitchen area.

We really enjoyed taking a self guided tour of this ship . Out of the 4 of us, only one had not previously seen this ship . 30 yrs ago my husband had seen it prior to the restoration .The set up of the ship and the cargo was very realistic.Nicely restoredPleasant staff and lovely manicured landscape and...

While in Whitehorse we visited the S.S. Klondike, we were very impressed with its presentation. It cost $12 for 2 adults and we spent about an hour walking around exploring the old paddlesteamer. Well worth a visit!

We visited the SS Klondike when it was pouring with rain but it ruin the experience.The tour guide was really knowledge and friendly.It was really interesting to find out the history of the Klondike and see how first class and second class travelled and how expensive it was.
All around excellent tour. It was part of our HAL tour and we were not disappointed. Our tour guide was bright, enthusiastic and full of interesting knowledge.
We toured the S.S. Klondike during our stay in Whitehorse. The tour is excellent - very informative, very interesting. The tour guide does a great job.

This is a Canada park and is well maintained. Although you can do a self guided tour, wait for the tour that's given on the hour. The restoration of this flagship of fleet is very good. You'll get a better appreciation of the importance of these supply ships in forming the Yukon Territory of today.
Ease of finding parking in a open air venue keeps the feel of of what the passengers would of felt 100 years ago. This ship is perfectly preserved.
The Klondike Paddlewheeler is beautifully restored including all of the supplies, equipment, even the bedding, dishes, etc. Really a wonderful walk down Yukon history... Very enjoyable!
Just the fact that this boat still exists and I can walk its old planks and feel its spirit is good enough for me.

This ship has a ton of history and the panels are very easy to read if you decide to forgo the guided tour as we did. The boat is also very well-maintained and you feel like it is exactly as it would have been back in the day.Tip: If you have time, there is a very interesting and well-made...
This boat is filled with history of the gold rush days. Well worth the time.
You can board and tour the ship which used to ply the Yukon River to Dawson City. Located in a beautiful location on the river with great mountain views.

Boat is fascinating, along with the stories of the men that had operated it. Parks Canada guides were a rich source of historical anecdotes, too. Very worthwhile tour for glimpses into the history of the Klondike.
This is a fabulously restored part of Yukon history! Been living here over 30 years and this is still a favourite.

Very interesting, a lot of history there, Guides were always upbeat, however tours are only offered on the hour for the first part of the summer, but located right of river bank so lots to see if you have to wait
It was closed at March, but I think that a outside walk is enough

If there were one thing to see in Whitehorse that you wouldn't want to miss, this would be it! The government has spent vast sums of money in restoration, and the result is a great site for all the family.
Very informative and interesting. Found out lots about the operation of the paddle wheel boats and the people.
This is a excellent attraction by Parks Canada, and well worth the nominal fee. Make sure to watch the video in the wall tent to put the whole experience into context.
I love anything to do with history of the region. Is looked very picturesque in the snow.

I visit the SS Klondike twice since I lived here in Whitehorse. The story of the paddle wheelers are a very important part of the gold rush and the formation of the city itself. If you want to know why and when Whitehorse expand, settle, and boom again, visit this exhibit offer by Park Canada.You will truly enjoy it.Guided...
The S. S. Klondike is beautifully preserved and in a wonderful setting. Be forewarned, however, that it is not open during the winter, so you can only enjoy exterior views!
Just close your eyes and think about river and the river boats almost hundred years ago, it was all here and there - spirits of old days is still here - fantastic.....
Make sure you visit the S.S. Klondike and do the tour. I learned so much from the tour. It is definitely worth a visit and spend some time along the river, too!

I went there with my Dad about 4 years ago, and we had such a great time. What a cool paddlewheeler! The people were friendly, entertaining and knowledgeable, and we had a great time wandering around, learning about all of the history, we are history dorks.Check it out for sure!

This is one of the sites that everyone just ends up visiting. My father in law some how managed to slip on with a group - avoiding the cost of a ticket. Now in fairness to him, he would have gladly paid but the small building near the SS Klondike where it seemed to be the obvious place to buy...
This is a Canadian park site and extremely well done -- boat is beautifully restored and the guided tour was most interesting.
We love history so this was a given. Great history lesson.

We really enjoyed our tour on the S.S Klondike. Our tour guide was excellent and you could tell he loved sharing the history of this boat. It was real eye opener and a great introduction to the history of the gold mining of the Yukon. So beautifully restored. Well worth a visit. if you have time the DVD they show...

Parks Canada does an amazing job. We had an excellent guide, Greg, a young man who knew everything possible about the riverboats that travelled from Whitehorse to Dawson City in the first half of the 20th century. He provided an excellent tour of an amazing feat of engineering that responded to the demands of the Klondike Gold Rush.
This boat is a job well done with perserving it and the tours are great! we went twice and still enjoyed it the second time. Nice spot with lots of grass, videos are available.
